c74object.name: bach.funnel
c74object.description: Index each llll element by prepending an increasing integer to it, and wrapping them in a pair of parentheses.

objarg.name: offset
objarg.description: Sets the initial number for the indexing (see offset attribute). Defaults to 1.

objarg.name: step
objarg.description: Sets the initial step for the indexing (see step attribute). Defaults to 1.

method.name: bang
method.description: Outputs the indexed result on the most recently received input data.

method.name: llll
method.description: An llll in the first inlet will be indexed so that each element will be substituted by an llll in the form (index original_element). By default, index starts from 1 and increases by 1 for each element of the original llll. These parameters can be changed via the arguments or the attributes. For instance a list in the form X Y Z W becomes (1 X) (2 Y) (3 Z) (4 W).

attribute.name: offset
attribute.description: Set the initial number for the indexing (can be integer, rational or float). Defaults to 1.

attribute.name: out
attribute.description:
The out attribute is a sequence of characters identifying the outlet types (one character for each llll outlet). Characters can be one of the followings:
n (default): 'native' output: faster and more precise between bach objects, but unreadable by standard Max objects (an "bach.llll" message appears instead).
t: 'text' output: slower and limited in size, but readable by standard Max objects. A plain llll in text format is a generic Max message.
x: disabled output (nothing is output)
p: 'portal' output: only used by bach.portal to intercept the @out attribute specified while creating the abstraction (see bach.portal).
The native output is recommended, unless communication with standard Max messages is needed. Disabling unused outputs can be useful if extreme optimization of the patch is needed.

attribute.name: step
attribute.description: Set the step for the indexing (can be integer, rational or float). Defaults to 1.

c74object.discussion: From a list in the form X Y Z W one gets to a list in the form (1 X) (2 Y) (3 Z) (4 W), where the offset and step of the numbering can be set via attributes
